Subject: Re: [neat] Introduction and an os x query
X-Yahoo-Group-Post: member; u=255378794; y=8OYcAc6UInxGA1dJLXe5sK3bN2jkoAz_I774uJFsFRGAg2YacQ

My impelementation splits the system into two parts:
genetics and network.  A network is created from the
genetics, but the genetics cannot be updated from the
network.  If the genetics change, the network must be
reinstantiated.

The genetics are implemented by an abstract Gene
class.  Each type of gene implements the abstract
class.  The system currently only has two types of
genes, NeuronGenes and WeightGenes.  Each gene has a
label which is a simple unsigned integer which is
autoassigned when the gene is created or cloned.  Each
subclass must implement a compare method used to sort
genes of each type.

NeuronGenes are sorted by their label, thus they  must
be created in a specific order: input, bias, output,
hidden.  Hidden neuron genes can come anywhere in the
sequence, but must appear after the last non-hidden
neuron gene.

WeightGenes are sorted by their output neuron
connection label first, followed by their input neuron
connection label second.  The compare method for
weight genes is about thirty lines of code.

When the genetics are sorted, using STL with the
gene's compare method, everything lines up as expected
with innovations.  I only sort once, immediately after
the genetics have been created.  Both the network
creation code and the genetic mating code depend upon
a well sorted gene sequence.

A genepool is implemented using a hash table. 
Whenever a new gene is created, the hash table is used
to see if   
gene already exists.  In the case of a weight gene,
the hash function uses the output/input neuron label
pairing.  If the gene is found, a reference count is
increased and a pointer to the existing gene is
returned rather than creating a new gene.  Once each
epoch, the genepool is purged of any genes that no
longer have any references to help speed up searches.

It takes only seconds to create large populations with
huge networks.  My large test case has a population
with 5000 organisms of 100 neurons each.  It takes
only ten to twenty seconds real time to create the
population.  The majority of creation time is spent in
the speciation code, which may still be buggy.


--- Michael Rosario <michaelrosario_2003@...>
wrote:

> Just wondering... In your implementation, if you do
> not use innovation numbers, how do you line up genes
> for mating operations?
